transcription.text: hello everyone welcome back to the
course of Raspberry Pi Pico so in this
video I'm gonna show you how you can
make weather station using Raspberry Pi
Pico and dst11 temperature and humidity
sensor so without wasting any time let's
restart it
[Applause]
so to make the project we need few
components like LC display few jumper
wires DHT 11 temperature humidity sensor
Raspberry Pi Pico and a breadboard
so now let us see the connections
[Music]
thank you
so according to a circuit diagram I
already built the connections so now let
us move to the coding part
now let us come to the coding section
for this project we require four files
which is dsd.5 files velocity API dot Pi
Pico i2clc dot pi and Main dot Pi so we
have to to work in the main dot Pi files
first of all uh I declare i2c equals to
i2c and LCD equals to i2c LCD these are
basically the i2c pins and the LC
display and then
we have to declare that t equals to
sensor dot temperature H equals to
sensor dot humidity and sensor we have
to declare as tstl11
pin which we are using as a temperature
humidity sensor
then we have to use all the uh
all this thing the time job sleep one
TLC dot clear I already explained this
uh syntax in the my previous video you
can go through that big video or I will
give the link of the video in the
description you can watch from there
so these are the one this is my code let
us run the code and upload to the Pico
board
so after uploading the code to my
Raspberry Pi Pico you can see that my
temperature currently showing is 33.2
degree celsius and humidity is
54.0 percentage so in this way you can
make a weather station using Raspberry
Pi Pico and dst11 temperature sensor so
now check whether my temperature is
showing showing is exactly matching to
my actual value or not
so
[Music]
so let us check
[Music]
today's temperature
[Music]
So currently
it is showing that the today's
temperature 34 degree Celsius
uh and it is showing that 33.1 degree
celsius it is almost uh it is a at least
one point uh 1.1 degrees difference of
1.1 degree Celsius
so there is no not much the difference
between the measured value and actual
value the measure value is my uh that
temperature reading on my LC display and
my actual value is this 34 degree
Celsius
so in this way you can make a weather
station using Raspberry Pi Pico
so if you like my video then please like
share and subscribe for more upcoming
videos
thank you
[Music]

visual_description.description: The host is visible on screen with a friendly smile, sitting in front of a background related to electronics or coding. The text 'Raspberry Pi Pico' might be visible on the screen or on a whiteboard behind the host.

An LCD display is visible on the table, and the host might be explaining its role in the project. Jumper wires are also shown, either connected to the Raspberry Pi Pico or laid out on the table.
The DHT11 sensor is shown again, and the host might be demonstrating how to connect it to the Raspberry Pi Pico. The camera focuses on the connections.

The host is now in front of a computer, with the coding environment open on the screen. The camera might zoom in on the code or the host's hands as they type.

A person is likely sitting in front of a computer screen displaying code, possibly in a coding environment or IDE. The code on the screen includes file names like 'dsd.5 files', 'velocity API dot Pi', indicating a programming project related to a Raspberry Pi or similar device. The computer screen continues to display code, with the person scrolling or typing, revealing more file names such as 'Pico i2clc dot pi' and 'Main dot Pi'. The coding environment or text editor is still visible, showing the person's work on the project.

The focus is still on the 'Main dot Pi' file, with the person's cursor possibly hovering or clicking within this file. The coding environment remains on the screen, indicating the person is working on this specific file.

The person starts typing in the 'Main dot Pi' file, declaring a variable 'i2c'. The code is being written or edited in the coding environment on the computer screen, with the person's fingers typing on the keyboard.

The person continues typing, declaring 'i2c' and 'LCD' variables, likely related to an I2C LCD display. The code is visible on the screen, showing the declarations and possibly some related comments or other code snippets.

The screen continues to show the coding environment with the 'i2c' and 'LCD' declarations. The person might be explaining or commenting on the code, possibly using a microphone if this is a tutorial or explanatory video.

The person declares a variable 't', potentially for temperature. The coding environment on the screen now includes this new variable, showing the progression of the code.

The code now includes 'sensor dot temperature' and 'H equals to sensor dot humidity', indicating the use of a sensor for temperature and humidity readings. The person's hands are on the keyboard as they work on the code.
